As a laptop user I close the compose box to see more messages on the screen if I am reading a long topic.
It is also useful for n key users not to accidentally type n into the compose box.

I close the compose box to see more messages on the screen if I am reading a long topic

We are talking here about 40px height vs 160px height. by closing compose box you are getting 120px of a vertical space.
I understand the value of that, but it feels like some friction to always expand and collapse it.
What if compose box would be open and not focused by default at all times, and there will be ability to collapse it on a view if you need it?

useful for n key users not to accidentally type n into the compose box

I think that could be managed with focused/not focused compose box.
Zulip doesn't close compose box when I'm switching topics of a stream but there is nothing yet inside the compose box while compose box is focused.

once you open the compose box, you expect the stream/topic or PM destination to only change if you manually change them. However, in an interleaved view, they would probably need to change as you scroll around (deftly switching between topics/targets).
So, you could maybe leave it open when narrowed to a topic, but keep the current behavior otherwise. (which might be confusing in a different way)

This is a complex topic, but a one part of it is that having the compose box open creates the expectations that typing keys goes into there, which makes it hard for keyboard shortcuts to work.

There's a significant visual attention / distraction cost to having the compose box open; having it closable means we can have a taller/more fancy compose experience with more buttons without the UI feeling cluttered when reading.

After reviewing the current redesign draft, I have a few comments on the compose box design. Posting a small screenshot here for reference, since it's a relatively isolated detail:

image.png

• One of the biggest proposed changes is having the compose box width match the width of a rendered message. It is definitely annoying for the compose box to be wider than the display area, in that paragraphs that look like reasonable in your compose box can look way too high after sending; I definitely find myself adding paragraph breaks when editing messages for this reason. So I think this potentially does solve a problem.
  • I worry that it will create a couple new user interaction problems: (1) It'll make long URLs that one might paste into the compose box, including our Markdown syntax for uploaded files, more unwieldy feeling. (2) It's possible that this will make it hard to work with code blocks of LaTeX syntax that one might be working on in the compose box. Possibly this second problem could be solved by extending the existing "full-height compose box" feature to support increased width as well, and there's potential solutions to the first problem (including some that would be a very large investment, like handling uploads via a WYSIWIG mechanism).

One observation about the potential downsides of changing the width is that our "message edit" UI already has the same width as a message, so that may be a useful source of intuition for whether it'd in practice either of the worries mentioned in the second bullet are real issues.

Here's a couple ideas that would lean further into the direction of having this greater width.

  • I think it's possible putting your avatar into the compose box to to the left of the textarea would make the design for this less-wide compose box look cleaner. Obviously, it's redundant information to show your avatar there, but I think the idea would be that it increases the illusion of your drafting a message that will soon appear in the message feed.
  • We could also put "NOW" in the space to the right of the text box where a timestamp would be -- with some sort of UI indication that you can click this to change the send time as how we do "Send later". We'd need to play with whether there's enough space to clearly indicate the time a message would be sent when you've enabled "Send later", but this might be another opportunity to make the space we're spending here feel useful and thematic.

• We'd need to have a mobile web design that's more different from the non-mobile web design, in that one wants all the width for the text box that one can get when composing a message on mobile. I think this is workable from an implementation complexity standpoint.

• I find the upwards-pointing arrow for the "Send" button to feel unnatural, and would probably go with the normal rightwards one if we're doing that button style. Also, I think we should avoid decreasing the size of the click target for the "Send" button; this is the single most important thing in the compose box and we should make sure it feels easy to hit with a mouse. (I think this design preserves its size, but wasn't sure).
• The "Preview" eye feels out of place to me. It's possible that other changes will make that no longer the case.

• I think the top row where you pick where to send the message has way too much emphasis on the stream/private message switching feature. We have tried designs with that approach before, and the problem is that it makes one feel like sending a message asks you too many questions -- first what type of message is it, then what stream, then what topic. Switching message type is an infrequent action, and we probably want it to be that way (by having users usually start composing a message the other way), and it also just feels distracting for it to have so much visual prominence.

    I do think it's logically correct for this to sit to the left, though. I think one possible solution would be to move it into the left column containing the preview icon (and your avatar below it), and rather than it being a dropdown just having it be a icon-sized toggle.

• One thing to keep in mind is that we currently use the bottom row space under the message to display 10005/10000 in red if the message is longer than our maximum message length (or close to it with a different color, I think). We can potentially move that indicator to be above the compose box if we want to use that space for something else, which is possible. E.g. I could imagine preview|write tabs being placed in that space as an alternative design for the preview toggle.

I worry that it will create a couple new user interaction problems: (1) It'll make long URLs... (2) ... make it hard to work with code blocks of LaTeX syntax

I'm not feeling great about the direction of having such a large STREAM|PM input element. There's a few concerns on my mind:

  • We currently have a visual pattern with the recipient bars in the message feed that you can just look at the left end of the recipient bar to read where a message was sent to, and having some extra text to the left breaks that pattern.
  • It's already visually obvious whether you're writing a PM or a stream message because of the 2-input vs. 1-input shape; I'd expect someone who's been using Zulip for more than a week to never find it useful to read the PM|STREAM labels.
  • The compose box design is otherwise very clean feeling, with essentially no text that stands out as something you're supposed to read other than the details of the message itself (recipient, content).
This is really tricky, because from a hierarchy standpoint, a STREAM/PM switcher should be to the left of the stream input.

I can think of a couple options that would address this issue:

  • Have the PM/stream switch element be hidden behind a 3-dot menu sort of thing in the corner. I think we probably don't want that, since an extra click is probably pretty significant in terms of the utility of this sort of widget.
  • Having it be represented by a single icon, with something indicating "switch", like https://fontawesome.com/v4/icon/random, and have the explanation of what it does be in tooltip (say, "Switch to private message" or "Switch to stream message").

A few other smaller notes:

  • The space to the right of the send button kinda bugs me; what would it look like if we made the send button a bit wider so that it extended to the edge? image.png
  • Somehow the pipes/separators between the groups of icons feel like they're an icon for a compose option that happens to be a pipe. Maybe the separator icons should be in a slightly lighter font?

I like the edit UI's look and feel overall! A few notes on that:

  • I like the save button, and would be very happy to replace the old style buttons with it. The cancel button feels a bit off / hard to read -- maybe the issue is the border being much darker than the label?
  • I think we might want to keep the two "Send notification" options on their own lines -- I seem to recall we went with that structure because it was really hard to avoid it looking bad with i18n for languages like German where text tends to be wider.

I think my final concern is I'm very reluctant to rework our closed-compose UI to be a small click target in the corner. We can test if necessary, since it's possible I'm wrong on this, but I feel pretty worried that it will result in intense criticism that sending a message in Zulip is too hard / too many steps / not chatty enough. All of our competitors go with an always-open feeling compose box, and having to move your mouse to a relatively small click target in the lower-right corner of the message feed in order to start typing a message seems like it might be asking too much.

To be clear, I like the button design for it -- I think it's visually a much nicer way to provide the current compose options ... but I just worry that it could be a very large source of friction to move in that direction.

We currently have a visual pattern with the recipient bars in the message feed that you can just look at the left end of the recipient bar to read where a message was sent to, and having some extra text to the left breaks that pattern.

Tim Abbott and I did a bit of brainstorming today on how we might address this comment, and here's a rough proposal we could chat about:

  1. As Vlad Korobov proposed in our chat earlier this week, the way to switch from composing to a stream to composing a PM could be a "Private message" option inside the stream dropdown (shown above all other options). So no dedicated button would be required.
  2. In that case, what happens when you're inside a PM compose view? If we continue to show "Private message" inside a dropdown, we still have a situation where there's extra text to the left of the addressee(s).

I don't know if it would feel good, but an idea we came up with is to replace the "Private message" text in the dropdown with a simple "To:". You could still click on the dropdown to switch to a stream name as your compose target. The field could be narrower in the PM compose situation and wider when composing to a stream.

  1. If we do something like (2), we wouldn't need a "To:" inside the addressee text box. For consistency, this might also cause us to remove "Topic:" from the topic name box.

  2. The result of all that is that we'd need to re-add some kind of dedicated "go to conversation" button.

Anyway, there's a lot of cascading consequences, but maybe worth discussing. A much more minimal change would be to just go with the "Private message" in the stream dropdown idea, without all the rest. :)

Compose box design proposal update

After having a discussion about the compose box with @Alya Abbott and @Tim Abbott I have a proposal. Depending on the feedback after that I would like to move forward towards creating a realistic js/css version on a replit.com so we could feel that closer to reality and iterate faster on some design tunes.

To see all the screens in 100% scale go to Figma prototype (it is just a slides without any interactivity). If you want to see actual figma frames they are here.

Please ignore any UI outside the compose box.

1. Collapsed compose box

The main button looks like an input. Doesn't look disabled. There is a link to Drafts.
image.png

2. Hovered collapsed compose box

On desktop hover could be utilized to understand the potential intent of the user. So we could give an opportunity to create a new topic instead of opening compose box with the currently recognized topic
image.png image.png image.png

3. Opened compose box

By default the focused field is the compose text area. Unless a user clicked NEW TOPIC in case of which the focused input would be a topic name.
When we have mouse hover over the text area we are showing expand button on the top right corner.
Since compose box grows until about 50% of the screen height I don't think we should always show the expand button, so I suggest to show it only on mouse hover.
image.png image.png image.png

4. Compose box with a jump/scroll to view button

There is a desire to have such button visible and understandable. The current icon doesn't work for me. I suggest to have a text label.
image.png

The alternative could be more visible but tricky to implement and very unusual: image.png

5. Topic input

I suggest to don't have any cross to clear or any other special button to create a new topic. Once a user is in the input chances are it is easier to delete the text with a cursor or click a dropdown button.
I suggest to name default topic as common topic instead of general chat. General will be confused with the stream name and chat doesn't indicate that this is a topic. So if we want a field without extra labels like Topic: we should have a default topic name as a placeholder but also as a real name of the default topic.
image.png

In the opened drop down I suggest to have Common topic always on top and highlight is the same as placeholder of the topic field.
image.png

I'm not sure if we should keep common topic once a user types something
image.png

In all cases I suggest to highlight the current value and also the hovered item

6. Stream input dropdown

Tim suggested to make it as a button vs an input but make filtering possible. I'm not sure if we should suggest new stream creation right from here, but we could if filter doesn't find anything.
The main new idea here is that user can select Direct Message among the streams, which will change the compose box to a different view

image.png

7. Composing direct message

I'm calling it direct message because it is marketed better in my mind :smile:. Also I'm avoiding confusion with private stream. I know that we didn't agree on that but I'm wishing :smile:
Input allows at least 3 people without changing layout. If we have more than 1 row of names we could start block wrapping the ui elements.
I would like to have a simple drop down available for names selection. So a user can easily pick the recent/relevant people to message.

image.png

The new UI/UX for the compose-box looks fantastic and is much more user-friendly. However, I have a few suggestions that could further improve its usability and enhance the overall user experience.

  • The current placement of the New Topic button within the topic bar may not be easily recognizable to users. Moving it to a separate button above the Send button would draw more attention to it and make it more intuitive to locate.
    New-topic.png

  • With the current change, switching between streams and direct messages requires clicking the downward arrow. However, adding a button next to the visible button would allow for easy toggling between the two, and the dropdown would simply list available streams and direct message users.
    stream_toggle.png

Note that various ideas for a stream/PM switcher button were discussed, and even tested here; see #design > Convert replies between stream and private messages . We found that (a) while the functionality is useful, it's not used frequently, so we want to avoid cluttering the UI by making it too prominent, and (b) it's hard to make a button to do this whose functionality is intuitive/clear to users.
